evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observed and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters within the context of the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset, reflecting typical patterns of crew interaction failures.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observed and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is indicated by lack of warnings and assumptions among crew members as described.
Procedural deviations are distinct from communication breakdown as per discriminator definitions.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the event.
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document communication lapses and assumptions among crew members during pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset, reflecting typical patterns of crew interaction failures.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is characterized by lack of warnings and assumptions among crew as described.
The discriminator correctly distinguishes coordination failure from procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviations or mechanical failures instead of communication issues.
If crew had effective communication and warnings prior to the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H8, H10, H12) documents communication and coordination breakdown among crew consistent with key features of coordination failure, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in interpreting crew actions and intentions; no explicit procedural deviation evidence.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

The incident was caused by human factors rather than equipment failure
defeaters: If evidence of verified mechanical faults or repeat malfunctions during the pushback phase were found
If fault codes or bench checks indicated control system malfunction
If physical evidence showed hardware failure causing the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the pushback continued past the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite no reported mechanical faults; communication and procedural issues are indicated, favoring procedural deviation and communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on operator reports and observations

assumptions: The TRP marking is considered part of the environmental/marking deficiency scope.
Statements about the TRP size and clearance relate to marking adequacy and identifiability.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in subjective assessments of marking adequacy and visibility

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 within hist_baseline_t3_prefinal is available for analysis and review.

defeaters: If evidence showed that the pushback deviation was due to mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiency rather than procedural error
If communication breakdown evidence indicated the deviation was caused by coordination failure rather than procedural deviation

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, and H12 directly describe the procedural deviation in pushback execution and its availability for analysis, supporting the claim. The tug instructor's actions and communication context (H1-H3) confirm the procedural nature of the deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct contradictory evidence present; uncertainty could arise if further evidence on mechanical or environmental factors were introduced.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features relevant to Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations on 12-25 in hist_baseline_t3_prefinal, ensuring it fits the expected operational context.

assumptions: The TRP markings and procedures are standard and known to the crew
The absence of mechanical fault evidence implies procedural cause
The trainee and instructor's qualifications and training are adequate to identify procedural deviations
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or equipment failure causing the pushback beyond TRP
If communication breakdown was documented with explicit warnings missed or misunderstood
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible to the crew

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H9, H10, H12) shows the procedural deviation in pushback execution with the tug instructor taking over and continuing past the TRP despite known procedures and training, supporting alignment with key features of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations in the given context. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environmental deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in communication signals and visual warnings effectiveness; no direct mechanical failure evidence

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters within the context of the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

assumptions: Crew statements accurately reflect their perceptions and actions.
No undisclosed environmental or mechanical factors influenced the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, unambiguous marking deficiencies that directly caused the event, or if crew communication was shown to be adequate and no coordination failures occurred.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

defeaters: If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure were found

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common defeaters and maintains integrity within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: The described crew roles and communication represent typical operational conditions
No other external factors beyond those described influenced the procedural deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or intervention by headset operator or wingman preventing the deviation
If environmental or mechanical factors were primary causes rather than procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H3, H8, H10, H12) shows the procedural deviation involved clear crew roles and communication patterns, with no effective warnings or interventions from other crew members, supporting robustness against common defeaters within the specified scope.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication effectiveness and possible unreported environmental factors

children_spec.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance and inventory logs for equipment readiness and presence during the pushback event

children_spec.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform the pushback procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew rosters and duty logs to confirm presence and qualification of pushback operators at the time

children_spec.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between cockpit and ground crew during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication recordings and equipment status reports to verify communication availability

node.statement: The environmental/marking deficiency must be resistant to defeaters within the context of Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t3_prefinal.

assumptions: Assuming that the marking visibility and adequacy are the main factors influencing defeater resistance in this context.
Assuming that the lack of effective visual signals to stop the tug is related to marking/environmental deficiencies rather than solely procedural or communication failures.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members, or that communication and procedural compliance were the primary causes of the incident, this would change the assessment.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly address the adequacy and visibility of the TRP marking and the challenges in signaling the tug driver to stop, supporting that the environmental/marking deficiency must be resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or communication failures contributed more significantly than marking deficiencies

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not reachable via standard communication devices during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check communication device logs and records to verify if calls or messages to crew members were received or missed

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are visible and unobstructed under current conditions

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not degraded beyond recognition
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate the condition of markings for wear, fading, or damage

node.statement: Relevant environmental markings are physically present at the location

assumptions: Presence of TRP marking implies relevant environmental markings are physically present
No evidence indicates markings were missing or not physically present
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing or obscured
If crew or operators were unaware of the marking due to lack of visibility or absence

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the physical presence of the TRP marking at the location, and H13 notes the TRP was small but present, supporting that relevant environmental markings were physically present.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking adequacy and visibility; small size noted but presence confirmed

node.statement: Environmental markings are visible and unobstructed under current conditions

assumptions: Small size of TRP marking does not imply obstruction
No evidence of physical obstruction or environmental conditions impairing visibility
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured or not visible under current conditions
If crew or operators reported inability to see or identify the markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

node.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform the pushback procedure

assumptions: Qualification status as stated in evidence is accurate and complete
Presence of personnel implies availability to perform procedure
defeaters: If evidence showed personnel were unqualified or absent
If communication failures were documented as primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H9, H11, H12) shows qualified personnel were present and involved in the pushback procedure, supporting availability of qualified personnel and favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of personnel unavailability or communication failure; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness.

node.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between cockpit and ground crew during pushback

assumptions: Communication via interphone implies availability of clear communication channels
Lack of warnings does not imply absence of communication channels but possible procedural or attentional failures
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was malfunctioning or not used
If there was explicit indication that communication was not established or failed

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, and H12 directly indicate that communication channels between cockpit and ground crew were available but visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, supporting availability of communication channels during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite availability

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable via standard communication devices during the incident

assumptions: Communication via headset and interphone represents standard communication devices for crew
defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were attempting but failing to communicate via standard devices
If communication logs indicated loss of contact or device failure

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8, H12) shows crew communication was active and no indication that crew members were unreachable via standard devices; headset operator and wingman were present and communicating, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit statements about communication device failure or unreachability

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25 is resistant to known defeaters.

assumptions: No mechanical fault codes or bench checks were reported in the evidence
Procedural deviations and communication issues are sufficient to explain the incident
defeaters: If evidence of verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure were found
If bench checks or equipment fault traces were documented

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4, H8, H10, H12) indicates the incident was due to procedural deviations and communication lapses rather than mechanical/control failure, contradicting the claim that mechanical failure is resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical fault evidence; reliance on procedural and communication history

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: The presence of TRP markings and clearance as described implies availability of required pushback equipment.
No evidence indicates equipment unavailability or malfunction.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were missing or obscured or that required pushback equipment was unavailable or malfunctioning, this would favor environmental deficiency instead.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 indicate that the TRP was marked and visible but small, and that the visual signals for stopping the tug were insufficient and not always observed, supporting that the availability of required pushback equipment was adequate, favoring procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in adequacy of visual signals and small size of TRP

node.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not degraded beyond recognition

assumptions: Presence of TRP marking implies it was maintained and recognizable.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were faded, obscured, or otherwise not visible to the crew, that would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 describe the TRP marking and its visibility, indicating the environmental markings were present and identifiable, contradicting the claim that markings were degraded beyond recognition.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about marking degradation; small size noted but not degradation.

Headset operator ... knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. node.statement: Pushback equipment (tug and related tools) was available and operational

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H3, H8, H9, H11, H12) shows the tug and related equipment were present, operational, and controlled by qualified personnel, supporting availability and functionality of pushback equipment. No evidence indicates equipment failure, favoring procedural deviation over mechanical failure or environmental causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness but equipment presence and operation are clear.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice.
